questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with swelling on the right side of the neck. Ultrasound revealed a circumscribed cystic swelling with a fluid-filled level. The swelling was surgically excised and sent for histopathological examination. The image of which is shown below. Based on the given findings, which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the location of swelling, cystic nature of swelling with fluid level, and histology findings of a cyst lined with ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium, the most probable diagnosis is bronchogenic cyst.

Bronchogenic cyst:

  • These are discrete, extrapulmonary, fluid-filled masses lined by respiratory epithelium.
  • They are most commonly found in the middle mediastinum.
  • Histology will show ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium and a wall containing bronchial glands, cartilage, and smooth muscle.
  • In newborns, a bronchogenic cyst may compress a major airway and cause respiratory distress.

Explanation of other options:

Cystic teratoma (Option A): Cystic teratomas are germ cell tumours, which are usually solid and contain components of all three germ layers.

Thyroglossal cyst (Option B): These arise from remnants of thyroglossal ducts and are lined by stratified squamous epithelium when located near the base of the tongue or by pseudostratified columnar epithelium in lower locations. The fibrous cyst wall often includes lymphoid aggregates or thyroid remnants.

Branchial cleft cyst (Option C): These benign lesions usually appear on the upper lateral aspect of the neck along the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The slowly enlarging cysts are well circumscribed and usually lined by stratified squamous or pseudostratified columnar epithelium. The fibrous cyst walls typically contain lymphoid tissue with prominent germinal centres.

choices.text: It typically begins from the basal region of the lower lobes
Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden monocytes
Fibrosis and thickening of the wall can cause brown induration

questions.text: A 68-year-old female with a long-standing history of mitral stenosis presents with progressively worsening respiratory distress. On evaluation, findings were consistent with pulmonary oedema as the underlying aetiology. Which of the following statements is true regarding pulmonary oedema?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above clinical scenario suggests cardiogenic pulmonary oedema due to mitral stenosis, which has resulted in possible heart failure.

  • Pulmonary oedema can result from either elevation of pulmonary hydrostatic pressure or increased capillary permeability.
  • Pulmonary oedema is seen in left heart failure, mitral stenosis, pulmonary vein obstruction, and nephrotic syndrome, which results from an elevation in pulmonary hydrostatic pressure.
  • Irrespective of the underlying mechanism in the pathogenesis of pulmonary oedema, the fluid accumulation begins in the basal regions of the lungs because hydrostatic pressure is greatest in these sites (dependent oedema). (Option A ruled out)
  • Histologically, the alveolar capillaries are engorged, and there is an intralveolar transudate.
  • The alveoli often contain numerous macrophages laden with hemosiderin, called heart failure cells, which are derived from phagocytosed red cells. (Option B ruled out)
  • In long-standing pulmonary congestion (e.g., as seen in mitral stenosis), hemosiderin-laden macrophages are abundant, and fibrosis and thickening of the alveolar walls cause the soggy lungs to become firm and brown (brown induration). (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: Destruction of the walls of airspaces without fibrosis
Interstitial fibrosis of the lung parenchyma
Prominent bronchial smooth muscle cell hyperplasia

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of heavy smoking presents to OPD with a several-month history of cough and progressive dyspnoea. On examination, his chest is hyperresonant on percussion, and clubbing is present. X-ray shows hyperinflated lungs. Based on the findings, what will be the histopathological findings in the lung?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features of chronic smoking, progressive dyspnea, hyperresonant chest, and overinflated lungs strongly suggest emphysema.

Emphysema

  • Emphysema is defined by irreversible enlargement of the airspaces distal to the terminal bronchiole, accompanied by destruction of their walls without fibrosis.
  • Pathogenesis of the most significant event in emphysema - destruction of the alveolar wall is closely related to a deficiency of serum alpha-1 antitrypsin.
  • α1-Antitrypsinis a major inhibitor of proteases (particularly elastase) secreted by neutrophils during inflammation.
  • It is postulated that any injury (e.g., that induced by smoking) that increases the activation and influx of neutrophils into the lung leads to local release of proteases, which, in the absence of α1-antitrypsin activity, result in excessive digestion of elastic tissue and, with time, emphysema.

Morphology

  • Advanced emphysema produces voluminous lungs, often overlapping the heart anteriorly.
  • The hallmark histopathologic feature of emphysema is destruction of alveolar walls and airspace enlargement without accompanying fibrosis.
  • As alveolar walls are destroyed, there is a decrease in the capillary bed area.

Explanation of other options:

Interstitial fibrosis of the lung parenchyma (Option B): Interstitial fibrosis of the lung parenchyma is a hallmark microscopic finding seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

Lymphocytes restricted to the interstitium (Option C): This is a feature seen associated with interstitial pneumonia, which primarily consists of mild to moderate chronic interstitial inflammation, containing lymphocytes and a few plasma cells, in a uniform or patchy distribution.

Prominent bronchial smooth muscle cell hyperplasia (Option D): Hypertrophy and/or hyperplasia of the bronchial wall smooth muscle with increased extracellular matrix is seen in asthma.

questions.text: A 15-year-old child presents to the ER with respiratory distress. He complains of chest tightness, productive cough and wheezing. On examination, he is observed to use the accessory muscles of respiration. He also gives a similar history in past and a family history of allergy to pollen, and laboratory investigations show eosinophilia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Laboratory findings of eosinophilia, the presence of wheezing, family history of atopy, and accessory muscle use during episodes point strongly towards bronchial asthma.

  • Asthma is a chronic lung disease caused by increased responsiveness of the airways to a variety of stimuli.
  • Patients typically have paroxysms of wheezing, dyspnea, and cough.
  • Acute episodes of asthma may alternate with asymptomatic periods, or they may be superimposed on a background of chronic airway obstruction.
  • The consensus hypothesis attributes bronchial hyperresponsiveness in asthma to an inflammatory reaction to diverse stimuli, either extrinsic or intrinsic.
  • Extrinsic asthma is typically a childhood disease, whereas intrinsic asthma usually begins in adults.
  • In allergic asthma, serum IgE levels are raised.

Explanation of other options:

Acute bronchiolitis (Option A): Bronchiolitis typically occurs in infants, and the common causative agent is the respiratory syncytial virus.

Cystic fibrosis (Option C): Cystic fibrosis is characterised by chronic pulmonary disease, deficient exocrine pancreatic function, and other complications of inspissated/thickened mucus in several organs. A defective chloride channel, the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), is responsible for the condition.

Chronic bronchitis (Option D): Chronic bronchitis is defined clinically as a persistent cough with sputum production for at least 3 months in at least 2 consecutive years in the absence of any other identifiable cause.

choices.text: Thickening of the bronchiolar wall due to smooth muscle hypertrophy
Enlargement of the mucus-secreting glands of the trachea and bronchi

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker presents with a history of a productive cough for 4 months, with similar episodes every year for 3 years. A bronchial biopsy was taken, and the histopathological image is shown below. Based on the clinical history and histological findings, what is the most likely histopathological change observed in the airways?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Symptoms of a productive cough for more than 4 months for 3 years in a chronic smoker are characteristic of chronic bronchitis.

  • Chronic bronchitis is defined clinically as a persistent cough with sputum production for at least 3 months in at least 2 consecutive years in the absence of any other identifiable cause.
  • Longstanding chronic bronchitis is associated with progressive lung dysfunction, which may be so severe as to lead to hypoxemia, pulmonary hypertension, and cor pulmonale.

Microscopic features of chronic bronchitis

  • Chronic inflammation of the airways (Option C ruled out)
  • Thickening of the bronchiolar wall due to smooth muscle hypertrophy, deposition of extracellular matrix in the muscle layer, and peribronchial fibrosis (Option A ruled out)
  • Goblet cell hyperplasia and enlargement of the mucus-secreting glands of the trachea and bronchi. (Option B ruled out)
  • This increase can be assessed by the ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer to the thickness of the wall between the epithelium and the cartilage (Reid index).

choices.text: Dilation of the respiratory bronchioles with loss of elastic fibres
Interstitial and alveolar oedema with hyaline membrane formation
Remodelling of airways with smooth muscle hyperplasia and increased submucosal glands

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with a 3-year history of cough and intermittent respiratory distress presents to the ER with acute respiratory distress, chest tightness, productive cough and wheezing. He is observed to use accessory muscles of respiration. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum IgE and peripheral eosinophilia. Sputum microscopy shows increased eosinophils. Which histologic feature is most characteristic of his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's long history and classic symptoms of chest tightness, cough with sputum and wheezing, along with elevated serum IgE level, peripheral blood eosinophilia and eosinophils in sputum are suggestive of asthma.

  • Asthma is a heterogeneous disease, usually characterised by chronic airway inflammation and variable expiratory airflow obstruction.
  • It's a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Symptoms: wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough, which vary over time and in intensity.

Diagnosis:

  • Sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage specimens of patients with atopic asthma show:
    • Curschmann spirals: Result from the extrusion of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles.
    • Numerous eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals are composed of the eosinophil-derived protein galectin-10.
    • Creola bodies: Desquamated ciliated columnar epithelium.

Fig: A) Curschmann spirals; B) Charcot-Leyden crystals

  • Characteristic histopathological findings in asthma are collectively called airway remodelling, which includes:
    • Thickening of the airway wall
    • Sub-basement membrane fibrosis (due to deposition of type I and III collagens)
    • Increased vascularity
    • Increase in the size of the submucosal glands and number of airway goblet cells.
    • Hypertrophy and/or hyperplasia of the bronchial wall muscle with increased extracellular matrix.

Explanation of other options:

Dilation of the respiratory bronchioles with loss of elastic fibres (Option A): Dilatation of bronchioles with loss of elasticity is classically seen in emphysema. The hallmark histopathologic feature of emphysema is destruction of alveolar walls and airspace enlargement without accompanying fibrosis.

Inflammatory destruction of bronchial walls (Option B): Destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue by inflammation stemming from persistent or severe infections leads to permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles is characteristic of bronchectasis.

Interstitial and alveolar oedema with hyaline membrane formation (Option C): These are findings associated with ARDS. ARDS is a clinical syndrome of progressive respiratory insufficiency caused by diffuse alveolar damage in the setting of sepsis, severe trauma, or diffuse pulmonary infection. The characteristic histologic finding is hyaline membranes lining alveolar walls.

choices.text: Grossly, there is airway dilation sometimes up to 4 times
There is ulceration, squamous metaplasia with acute and chronic inflammatory infiltrate
Long-standing may form peribronchial fibrosis and the bronchial wall, leading to obstruction

questions.text: A 59-year-old male presents with a persistent and severe cough for 3 weeks, associated with foul-smelling expectoration and occasional hemoptysis, dyspnea and orthopnea. Chest X-ray showed opacities in the bilateral lower lobes and prominent vascular markings. Which of the following statements is true regarding the disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Persistent cough with foul-smelling expectorant, hemoptysis and bilateral involvement of the lower lobes of the lungs are hallmark features of bronchiectasis.

  • Bronchiectasis is a disorder in which destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue by inflammation stemming from persistent or severe infections leads to permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles.
  • Obstruction and infection are the major conditions associated with bronchiectasis.
  • Immotile cilia syndrome and cystic fibrosis can result in generalised bronchiectasis.
  • Bronchiectasis usually affects the lower lobes bilaterally, particularly air passages that are vertical, and is most severe in the more distal bronchi and bronchioles.
  • The airways are dilated, sometimes up to four times their normal size. (Option A ruled out)
  • The histologic findings vary with the activity and chronicity of the disease.
  • In the full-blown, active case, there is an intense, acute and chronic inflammatory exudation within the walls of the bronchi and bronchioles, associated with desquamation of the lining epithelium and extensive ulceration. (Option B ruled out)
  • Fibrosis of the bronchial and bronchiolar walls and peribronchiolar fibrosis develop in more chronic cases, leading to varying degrees of subtotal or total obliteration of bronchiolar lumens. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with high-grade fever and acute respiratory distress. X-ray revealed diffuse bilateral infiltrates. Laboratory investigations showed neutrophilic leukocytosis, with ABG analysis indicating hypoxemia. A transbronchial lung biopsy was performed, the histopathological image of which is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical triad of acute respiratory distress, diffuse bilateral infiltrates, and hypoxemia, along with histology showing hyaline membranes lining distended alveolar ducts and sacs, is suggestive of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). The histologic pattern seen in ARDS is Diffuse Alveolar Damage (DAD).

Acute respiratory distress syndrome:

  • Also known as:
    • Diffuse alveolar injury
    • Hyaline membrane disease
    • Shock lung
  • Clinical features include dyspnoea with a normal cardiovascular system
  • Damage to endothelial and alveolar epithelial cells and secondary inflammation are the key initiating events and the basis of lung damage.
  • The characteristic histologic finding is hyaline membranes lining alveolar walls, accompanied by oedema, scattered neutrophils and macrophages, and epithelial necrosis.
  • Diffuse alveolar damage is the earliest event to occur in ARDS.

Explanation of other options:

Atypical pneumonia (Option B): The most common causative agents include Mycoplasma and Chlamydia. They present with low-grade fever, malaise. A chest X-ray will sometimes show areas of consolidation.

Asthma (Option C): Asthmatic patients present with wheezing, breathlessness, and cough, especially at night. Histology shows goblet cell hyperplasia, smooth muscle hypertrophy, and eosinophilic inflammation. It affects the bronchi, not the alveoli, and does not produce hyaline membranes.

Tuberculosis (Option D): Patients with Pulmonary TB present with chronic cough and associated weight loss and loss of appetite. Histology will show caseating granulomas with Langhans giant cells.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents to the ER with respiratory distress. He gave a 2-week history of persistent and severe cough with foul-smelling expectorant associated with hemoptysis, dyspnea and orthopnea. Chest X-ray showed opacity in the bilateral lobes with prominent vascular markings and an air-fluid level. However, despite all efforts, the patient died due to respiratory failure. A gross specimen of the lung obtained during autopsy is shown below. Based on the above history and gross findings, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clinical features like foul-smelling expectoration, hemoptysis, air-fluid levels on chest radiograph, and gross specimen of lung showing dilated bronchi filled with mucopurulent secretions are suggestive of bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis

  • Usually affects the lower lobes bilaterally.
  • Bronchiectasis can be:
    • Localised: As in tumour or aspiration of foreign bodies.
    • Generalised: In conditions like immotile cilia syndrome and cystic fibrosis
  • Clinical features:
    • Severe, persistent cough
    • Expectoration of foul-smelling, sometimes bloody sputum and hemoptysis;
    • Dyspnea and orthopnea in severe cases

Gross features

  • The airways are dilated, sometimes up to four times their normal size.
  • On the cut surface of the lung, the dilated bronchi appear cystic and are filled with mucopurulent secretions.

Histology features

  • Inflammatory exudation within the walls of the bronchi and bronchioles
  • Desquamation of the lining epithelium and extensive ulceration.
  • In some instances, necrosis destroys the bronchial or bronchiolar walls and forms a lung abscess.
  • Fibrosis of the bronchial and bronchiolar walls and peribronchiolar fibrosis develop in more chronic cases, leading to varying degrees of subtotal or total obliteration of bronchiolar lumens.

Explanation of other options:

Asthma (Option A): In patients dying of acute severe asthma, the lungs are overinflated and contain small areas of atelectasis. The most striking gross finding is occlusion of bronchi and bronchioles by thick, tenacious mucus plugs, which often contain shed epithelium.

Emphysema (Option B): Generally, in patients with smoking-related diseases like emphysema, the upper two-thirds of the lungs are more severely affected. Large alveoli can easily be seen on the cut surface of fixed lungs. Apical blebs or bullae characteristic of irregular emphysema may appear in patients with advanced disease.

Chronic bronchitis (Option D): Chronic bronchitis is defined as a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. Grossly, there is hyperemia, swelling, and oedema of the mucous membranes, frequently accompanied by excessive mucinous or mucopurulent secretions.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female admitted with 50% burns develops respiratory distress, high-grade fever with chills and productive cough during her hospital stay. Laboratory investigations showed neutrophilic leukocytosis with left shift, raised procalcitonin and a positive blood culture. Chest X-ray shows bilateral diffuse pulmonary consolidation. A transbronchial biopsy was performed, and the histopathological image of the lung is shown below. Which stage of pneumonia is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of fever and productive cough, along with laboratory findings of raised procalcitonin and a positive blood culture, suggests pneumonia with possible sepsis. The histology shows neutrophilic infiltrates and vascular congestion in alveoli, indicating the red hepatisation stage of lobar pneumonia.

4 stages of lobar pneumonia:

  • Stage of congestion: In the first stage of congestion, the lung is heavy, boggy, and red. It is characterised by vascular engorgement, intra-alveolar oedema fluid containing a few neutrophils, and the presence of bacteria, which may be numerous. (Option A ruled out)
  • Red hepatisation: In this stage, there is massive confluent exudation, as neutrophils, red cells, and fibrin fill the alveolar spaces. On gross examination, the lobe is red, firm, and airless, with a liver-like consistency, hence the name hepatisation.
  • Grey hepatisation: This stage is marked by progressive disintegration of red cells and the persistence of a fibrinosuppurative exudate, resulting in a colour change to grayish-brown. (Option C ruled out)
  • Stage of resolution: In the final stage of resolution, the exudate within the alveolar spaces is broken down by enzymatic digestion to produce granular, semifluid debris that is resorbed, ingested by macrophages, expectorated, or organised by fibroblasts growing into it. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Anthracosis - Macrophages laden with carbon pigments

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a 3-year history of progressive respiratory distress. He has worked as a stone carver for the past 30 years. Chest X-ray shows nodularity in the upper zone of the lung. The patient was managed conservatively but died of congestive heart failure after 2 days. Autopsy was done, and given below is the histopathological examination of the lung nodule. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the characteristic histological feature?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of chronic respiratory distress in a long-term stone carver, along with histology showing concentric whorled collagen fibres, suggests the diagnosis of silicosis.

Silicosis:

  • Also known as knife grinder's disease.
  • Silicosis is a common lung disease caused by inhalation of proinflammatory crystalline silicon dioxide (silica/quartz).
  • It usually presents after decades of exposure as slowly progressing, nodular, fibrosing pneumoconiosis.
  • Commonly seen in those involved in stone cutting, sandblasting, and mining.
  • Upper lobes of the lung are usually involved.
  • With time, via lymphatics, fibrosis and calcification occur in hilar lymph nodes, giving a typical X Ray appearance of Eggshell calcifications.

Histology features:

  • A hallmark lesion is a silicotic nodule characterised by a central area of whorled collagen fibres with a more peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages.
  • The collagenous silicotic nodules start fusing, forming nodular masses greater than 2 cm in diameter, resulting in progressive massive fibrosis.

Explanation of other options:

Anthracosis - Macrophages laden with carbon pigments (Option A): Anthracosis is the most innocuous coal-induced pulmonary lesion in coal miners. Inhaled carbon pigment is engulfed by alveolar or interstitial macrophages, which accumulate in the connective tissue adjacent to the lymphatics and organised lymphoid tissue adjacent to the bronchi or in the lung hilus.

Asbestosis - Ferruginous bodies (Option B): Asbestosis is marked by parenchymal interstitial fibrosis resulting from asbestos exposure. Pleural plaques, the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. Hallmark microscopic findings are the presence of asbestos bodies and ferruginous bodies.

Sarcoidosis - Non-caseating granulomas (Option C): Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease characterised by well-formed non-necrotising granulomas composed of aggregates of tightly clustered epithelioid macrophages, often with giant cells.

questions.text: A 65-year-old coal miner with a history of heavy smoking is admitted with severe respiratory distress. Physical examination revealed a barrel-shaped chest and the use of accessory muscles. Chest radiographs showed nodular opacity in the upper zone of the lungs. A transbronchial lung biopsy was performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above-explained clinical findings and history in a coal worker, with the histology showing carbon-laden macrophages, indicate anthracosis.

  • Anthracosis is the most innocuous coal-induced pulmonary lesion in coal miners.
  • Inhaled carbon pigment is engulfed by alveolar or interstitial macrophages.
  • Carbon deposits are dark black and are readily visible grossly and microscopically.
  • The upper lobes and upper zones of the lower lobes are more heavily involved.
  • They are located primarily adjacent to respiratory bronchioles, the site of initial dust accumulation.
  • In a minority of cases, progressive massive fibrosis develops, leading to increasing pulmonary dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension, and cor pulmonale.

Explanation of other options:

Silicosis (Option A): Silicosis is commonly seen in those involved in stone cutting, sandblasting, and mining. Upper lobes of the lung are usually involved, and chest radiographs show upper lobe nodularity, while histology reveals characteristic silicotic collagenous nodules.

Asbestosis (Option C): Asbestosis is marked by parenchymal interstitial fibrosis, with the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure being pleural plaques. Hallmark microscopic findings are the presence of asbestos bodies and ferruginous bodies.

Sarcoidosis (Option D): Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease, and the lungs are the most commonly affected organ. Radiologically, a diffuse reticulonodular infiltrate is typical, but occasional cases may show larger nodules. Histologically, multiple well-formed non-caseating granulomas are scattered in the interstitium of the lung.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 65-year-old factory worker with a long history of smoking presents with gradually worsening breathlessness and a productive cough for 3 years. Chest X-ray showed irregular linear densities in both lower lobes of the lung. A transbronchial lung biopsy was taken from the opaque region, and the histology image is shown below. Which histological feature is most characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Histology shows ferruginous bodies, which are characteristic of asbestosis.

Asbestosis

  • Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and is characterised by the presence of asbestos bodies.
  • Asbestos bodies are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods with a translucent centre that consist of asbestos fibres coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material.
  • Other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes and are called ferruginous bodies.

Clinical features

  • Dyspnea is usually the first manifestation; at first, it is provoked by exertion, but later is present even at rest.
  • Cough associated with the production of sputum, when present, is likely to be due to smoking rather than asbestosis.

Manifestations

  • Interstitial fibrosis - more severe in the lower zones of lung.
  • Pleural plaques - the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure; more severe in the posterior and diaphragmatic surfaces of the pleura.
  • High risk for lung carcinomas and mesotheliomas.

Fig: Gross specimen of the lung with asbestosis

Explanation of other options:

Carbon-laden macrophages (Option A): Carbon-laden macrophages within alveolar spaces or interstitial tissue are characteristic microscopic findings in anthracosis.

Collagenous nodules (Option B): An important, remarkable histology feature in silicosis is silicotic collagenous nodules. These nodules are always less than 1 cm. Silicosis commonly affects the upper lobes of the lungs. Chest radiographs show upper lobe nodularity.

Fig: Masson trichome-stained silicotic nodule

Caseating granuloma (Option D): The most classic cause which shows caseating granuloma is tuberculosis. The granulomas are usually enclosed within a fibroblastic rim punctuated by lymphocytes. Multinucleated giant cells are present in the granulomas.

questions.text: A 59-year-old chronic smoker presents with shortness of breath associated with hemoptysis and a productive cough. He reports weight loss, and examination showed digital clubbing. Chest radiograph revealed a mass in the right lung apex, from which a biopsy was taken. The histopathology image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC):

  • The most common cancer associated with smoking (numerically).
  • The most common genetic mutation associated with SCC is p53. Also associated with P16 and FGFR1.
  • Most squamous cell carcinomas arise centrally in the lung from major or segmental bronchi.
  • Associated with cavity formation and massive necrosis.
  • It is commonly associated with Pancoast tumour manifestation.
  • The most common paraneoplastic manifestation is hypercalcemia, due to secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP).

Morphology: Can be of three types based on keratin production:

  • Keratinising (Well-Differentiated): Shows keratin pearls (keratin in the centre with malignant squamous cells arranged around it). Indicates good differentiation.
  • Non-Keratinising: No keratin in the centre.
  • Basaloid: Arises from basal cells of the squamous epithelium, with more basic cells.

Diagnosis:

  • Electron microscopy: Shows desmosomes, which are always present.
  • IHC: The most specific marker is P40. Also positive for P63. Can be positive for CK5/6.

Explanation of other options:

Adenocarcinoma (Option B): Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumour which usually arises in the peripheral part of the lung. These tumours are common in females and non-smokers. It is characterised by glandular differentiation or mucin production by the tumour cells.

Small cell carcinoma (Option C): These are the most common malignant neuroendocrine tumours of the lung. Small cell carcinoma is composed of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli. They show the Azzopardi effect and extensive necrosis.

Non-small cell carcinoma (Option D): These are epithelial tumours of the lungs which include squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma and large cell carcinoma. These tumours always have a precursor lesion.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with dyspnea and hemoptysis associated with productive cough and chest pain for 4 months. Chest x-ray showed a small mass in the periphery of the right lung. A transbronchial lung biopsy was performed; the histopathology image is shown below. What can be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above clinical presentation and histology findings of columnar and mucus-secreting cells growing along alveoli are characteristic of adenocarcinoma of the lungs.

Adenocarcinoma of the lungs:

  • Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumour which usually arises in the peripheral part of the lung.
  • Common in females and non-smokers.
  • Genetic predisposition:
    • Never Smokers (People who have never smoked): They most commonly have the EGFR mutation.
    • Nonsmokers (includes former smokers): The most common mutation is KRAS.
  • These tumours have a precursor sequence: Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia (AAH) → adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) → adenocarcinoma.
    • AAH: Atypical columnar cells lining alveoli, area < 5mm.
    • AIS: Columnar cells lining alveoli (> 5mm but < 3cm), previously called bronchoalveolar carcinoma (BAC). Shows a lepidic pattern ("butterfly sitting on a fence" - columnar cells lining alveoli).
    • Adenocarcinoma: Cells start forming glands and infiltrating the stroma.
  • The most common paraneoplastic manifestation associated with adenocarcinoma is hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

Diagnosis:

  • Nuclear Marker: Thyroid Transcription Factor 1 is a helpful nuclear marker.
  • IHC: Positive for Napsin and CK7. (CK5/6 negative, distinguishing from SCC & mesothelioma).
  • Electron microscopy: Typically has short and stout microvilli.
  • Morphology: Can show glands and mucin production. AIS shows a lepidic pattern.

Explanation of other options:

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option A): Histologically, squamous cell carcinoma is characterised by the presence of keratinisation and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinisation may take the form of squamous pearls or individual cells with markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Small cell carcinoma (Option C): Most squamous cell carcinomas arise centrally in the lung. Small cell carcinoma is composed of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli.

Carcinoid tumours (Option D): These low-grade malignant epithelial neoplasms are neuroendocrine tumours. Nests of tumour cells, also called islands or insular pattern, or trabecular pattern. The cells are well-defined, perfectly rounded cells with fine chromatin and some coarse chromatin, giving a characteristic salt and pepper chromatin appearance. This chromatin is typical of most neuroendocrine tumours.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 63-year-old male chronic smoker presents with gradually worsening breathlessness and a productive cough. On evaluation, chest X-ray showed a central lung mass and a transbronchial biopsy was performed. Histopathological examination confirmed a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma. Which immunohistochemical marker would most likely show positive expression to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

p40 and p63 are the common IHC markers showing positive expression in squamous cell carcinoma.

IHC markers of squamous cell carcinoma:

  • Most specific - p40
  • Also positive for p63, CK5/6

Explanation of other options:

TTF-1 (Option B), Napsin (Option D): TTF-1 and Napsin A expression are seen with adenocarcinoma. TTF-1 is a nuclear marker. Adenocarcinoma is also positive for CK7.

NSE (Option C): NSE (neuron-specific enolase) is expressed in small cell carcinoma, along with other neuroendocrine markers, like Synaptophysin, Chromogranin, CD56, and Bombesin.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Tumour comprising small cells with scant cytoplasm
Tumour cells have fine granular nuclear chromatin, with nuclear moulding
Tumour cells show marked nuclear pleomorphism with prominent nucleoli
The Azzopardi effect can be seen

questions.text: A 68-year-old from a rural area with a history of bidi and hookah use since childhood presents with gradually worsening respiratory symptoms for 4 months. Chest X-ray and CT scan showed a mass in the periphery of the left lung. A transbronchial lung biopsy was performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the histopathological findings of the tumour is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathological image and the clinical context are characteristic of small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC). Nuclear polymorphism with prominent nucleoli is not a histological feature of small cell carcinoma. Large cell carcinoma shows a large nucleus with prominent nucleoli and abundant cytoplasm.

Histology features of small cell carcinoma:

  • Comprises relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders. (Option A ruled out)
  • Finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. ((Option B ruled out))
  • The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear moulding is prominent.
  • Cells are fragile and break, causing streaking (blue streaks).
  • Azzopardi effect: Basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumour cells. (Option D ruled out)
  • Extensive necrosis due to rapid growth outpacing the blood supply.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male presents with hemoptysis and weight loss over the past 3 months. An HRCT scan revealed a mass circumscribing the right main bronchus protruding into its lumen. An endobronchial lung biopsy was taken; the histopathological image is shown below.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Histopathology shows uniform round cells with salt and pepper chromatin. Histology findings, along with clinical symptoms and endobronchial tumour, suggest a carcinoid tumour.

Carcinoid tumours

  • Malignant neuroendocrine tumours, which arise from Kulchitsky cells, are seen in the respiratory and GI mucosa.
  • It usually arises in the central part of the lung, specifically in the central bronchi.

Histology

  • Nests of tumour cells, also called islands/insular pattern, or trabecular pattern.
  • The cells are well-defined, perfectly rounded cells with fine chromatin and some coarse chromatin, giving a characteristic salt and pepper chromatin appearance.

Diagnosis:

  • Tumour marker: Increased levels of hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) in urine. Low niacin levels in the blood.
  • IHC: Positive for neuroendocrine markers: Synaptophysin, Chromogranin, CD56, and INSM1 (a nuclear marker).
  • Electron Microscopy: Shows dense core granules

Explanation of other options:

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option A): Histologically, squamous cell carcinoma is characterised by the presence of keratinisation and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinisation may take the form of squamous pearls or individual cells with markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Adenocarcinoma (Option B): Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumour with glandular differentiation or mucin production by the tumour cells. Adenocarcinomas grow in various patterns, including acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid.

Small cell carcinoma (Option C): Small cell carcinoma is composed of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli.

choices.text: CMV pneumonitis due to viral cytopathic effect
Small cell carcinoma lung with malignant infiltration

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was admitted with severe respiratory distress. On examination, he had pedal oedema and bilateral crepitus on auscultation. Despite the treatment, he expired 2 days after admission. An autopsy was performed, and a histopathology image of a lung biopsy is shown below. Which of the following best describes the diagnosis and the underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Histopathology shows brown-colored macrophages with hemosiderin, called the heart failure cells, which are typically seen in left heart failure due to the chronic pulmonary candida.

  • In chronic venous congestion (CVC), there is long-standing accumulation of deoxygenated blood; hence, there is damage to the tissues.
  • Gross Appearance
    • Lungs are heavy
    • Appear brownish (Brown induration of the lungs)

Pathogenesis:

  • Macrophages of alveoli, called the dust cells, consume carbon pigment.
  • The alveolar septa appear widened & fibrotic (Widened Interstitium). Alveoli are dilated and contain oedema fluid, RBCs and macrophages.
  • Due to the massive stagnation, rupture of the congested vessel occurs, resulting in oedema and haemorrhage.
  • Macrophages consume the excess RBCs from the congestion. Haemoglobin is broken down into hemosiderin within the macrophages, thus forming hemosiderin-laden macrophages.
  • These hemosiderin-laden macrophages are called heart failure cells.

Explanation of other options:

CMV pneumonitis due to viral cytopathic effect (Option A): CMV infections are commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, and histology is characterised by owl eye appearance due to prominent intranuclear inclusion.

Small cell carcinoma lung with malignant infiltration (Option B): Small cell carcinoma is a neuroendocrine tumour, and patients present with gradually worsening respiratory symptoms like breathlessness, productive cough and even weight loss. Histology shows sheets of small, round blue cells with scant cytoplasm, nuclear moulding, and salt and pepper chromatin appearance.

Tuberculosis with granulomatous inflammation (Option C): Patients with tuberculosis present with chronic cough, weight loss and evening rise of temperature. Histology will show caseating granulomas with Langhans giant cells.

questions.text: A factory worker has been working in a factory for the past 20 years, and now presents with pleural thickening and fibrosis. The histopathology of the lesion is shown in the image below. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Note the brown colored alveoli suggestive of asbestosis.

questions.text: A middle-aged immunocompromised male presents with fever and breathlessness. HRCT showed a middle lobe lesion with infiltration. A lung biopsy was obtained from the lesion, and the histopathology image is shown below. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above clinical presentation in an immunocompromised patient, along with histopathology showing a soap bubble appearance, is characteristic of Cryptococcus infection. The diagnosis is further supported by staining of the capsule of Cryptococcus with mucicarmine.

  • Cryptococcal pneumonia presents as diffuse progressive pulmonary disease.
  • Because of its thick capsule, C. neoformans stains poorly with the routine hematoxylin and eosin stain and appears as bubbles or holes in tissue sections.
  • Fungal stains (PAS and GMS) demonstrate the yeasts well but do not stain the polysaccharide capsule. The organism thus appears to be surrounded by a halo.
  • The capsule can be highlighted by the mucicarmine stain.

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculosis pneumonia (Option A): Both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients can be affected. TB usually affects the upper lobes, and a biopsy would show granulomas with Langhans giant cells.

Small cell carcinoma lung (Option C): SCCL presents with a history of worsening breathing difficulty, cough, weight loss and sometimes hemoptysis. Lesions are commonly seen centrally and arise in those with a strong history of smoking. Histology shows sheets of small, round blue cells with scant cytoplasm, nuclear moulding, and salt and pepper chromatin appearance.

CMV pneumonia (Option D): Cytomegalovirus infection affects immunocompromised individuals and leads to interstitial pneumonia. It is characterised by the enlargement of infected cells & prominent intranuclear inclusion (Owl's eye appearance).

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a smoking history presents with a productive cough for 3 months. He reports having similar episodes for the last 3 years. On examination, coarse crackles are heard over both lungs. A bronchial biopsy is performed, and the histopathology image is shown below. Which of the following conditions best explains the histological findings seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology image shows an increased ratio of submucosal mucin gland layer to bronchial wall layer, increasing the Reid index. When correlated with the clinical history of a productive cough lasting at least 3 months for 3 consecutive years, the findings are characteristic of chronic bronchitis.

  • Chronic bronchitis is defined clinically as a persistent cough with sputum production for at least 3 months in at least 2 consecutive years in the absence of any other identifiable cause.

Microscopic features of chronic bronchitis:

  • Chronic inflammation of the airways (predominantly lymphocytes and macrophages) (Option C ruled out)
  • Thickening of the bronchiolar wall due to smooth muscle hypertrophy, deposition of extracellular matrix in the muscle layer, and peribronchial fibrosis (Option A ruled out)
  • Goblet cell hyperplasia and enlargement of the mucus-secreting glands of the trachea and bronchi. (Option B ruled out)
  • This increase can be assessed by the ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer to the thickness of the wall between the epithelium and the cartilage (Reid index).

Explanation of other options:

Bronchiectasis (Option A): Presents with foul-smelling expectoration, hemoptysis, air-fluid levels on chest radiograph, and gross specimen of lung shows dilated bronchi filled with mucopurulent secretions. Microscopically, Inflammatory exudation within the walls of the bronchi and bronchioles, with desquamation of the lining epithelium and extensive ulceration, can be seen.

Interstitial lung disease (Option B): These are restrictive lung diseases characterised by patchy interstitial fibrosis, fibroblastic foci, and formation of cystic spaces (honeycomb lung). Velcro crepitus on auscultation is a characteristic finding.

Emphysema (Option D): Emphysema is the irreversible enlargement of the airspaces distal to the terminal bronchiole. Clinically, patients present with a hyperresonant chest, and chest radiograph shows hyperinflated lungs. The hallmark histopathologic feature of emphysema is destruction of alveolar walls and airspace enlargement without accompanying fibrosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of smoking for the last 15 years died of severe respiratory distress. Autopsy of the lungs reveals the following histopathological findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The gross specimen of the lung shows dilated air spaces with surrounding normal lung parenchyma, hence the diagnosis of centriacinar emphysema, which is strongly associated with smoking.

Based on the segments of the respiratory units that are involved, emphysema is subdivided into four major types:

  • Centriacinar
  • Panacinar
  • Paraseptal
  • Irregular

Centriacinar emphysema

  • Most common form.
  • Occurs predominantly in heavy smokers with COPD.
  • In this type of emphysema, the central or proximal parts of the acini, formed by respiratory bronchioles, are affected, whereas distal alveoli are spared.
  • The lesions are more common in the upper lobes, particularly in the apical segments.

Panacinar (panlobular) emphysema: (Option B ruled out)

  • Panacinar emphysema is associated with α1-antitrypsin deficiency and is exacerbated by smoking.
  • In this type, the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal alveolus.
  • More common in the lower zones and the anterior margins of the lungs.

Distal acinar (paraseptal) emphysema:

  • Paraseptal (distal acinar) emphysema primarily affects the distal part of the acinus near the pleura, especially in the upper lobes
  • Bullae formation and spontaneous pneumothorax usually occur.

Irregular emphysema:

  • Irregular emphysema is associated with areas of fibrosis and is the most common type detected incidentally during autopsy.

Explanation of other options:

Chronic bronchitis (Option C): Grossly, there is hyperemia, swelling, and oedema of the mucous membranes, sometimes, heavy casts of secretions and pus fill the bronchi and bronchioles. The characteristic microscopic features are thickening of the bronchiolar wall due to smooth muscle hypertrophy, peribronchial fibrosis, goblet cell hyperplasia, and enlargement of the mucus-secreting glands. The Reid index (normally 0.4) is increased in chronic bronchitis.

Bronchiectasis (Option D): The Gross specimen of the lung will show dilated bronchi filled with mucopurulent secretions. Microscopically, inflammatory exudation within the walls of the bronchi and bronchioles, with desquamation of the lining epithelium and extensive ulceration, can be seen.

questions.text: A full-term neonate rapidly develops progressive respiratory distress shortly after birth and dies. The histopathology image from postmortem lung biopsy reveals the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histology image shows amorphous, eosinophilic proteinaceous deposits in alveoli, which in an infant indicates pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.

  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) is a rare disease caused by defects in pulmonary macrophage function due to deficient granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) signalling.
  • Results in the accumulation of surfactant in the intra-alveolar and bronchiolar spaces.
  • PAP is characterised radiologically by bilateral patchy asymmetric pulmonary opacifications.
  • Histology shows alveoli are filled with a dense, amorphous, protein-lipid granular precipitate, while the alveolar walls are normal.
  • The alveolar precipitate is pink, homogeneous, and periodic acid-Schiff-positive.

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary haemorrhage (Option A): In a classic case, the lungs are heavy, with areas of red-brown consolidation. Histologically, there is focal necrosis of alveolar walls associated with intra-alveolar haemorrhages. Often, the alveoli contain hemosiderin-laden macrophages.

Pneumonia (Option C): Pneumonia is characterised by neutrophilic infiltration of alveoli, which is not seen in this case.

Pulmonary oedema (Option D): Pulmonary oedema is the venous congestion of the lungs, which leads to the accumulation of a transudate in the alveoli. A hallmark feature seen in such cases is a macrophage laden with hemosiderin, called a heart failure cell.

questions.text: Which among the following tests is demonstrated in the image, and what is its clinical importance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a Mantoux test with induration, indicating a positive test, which suggests prior TB exposure.

Mantoux test:

  • The tuberculin test is based on the principle of type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • This test involves injecting purified protein derivative (PPD) intradermally into the flexor aspect of the forearm and is assessed after 48-72 hours.
  • An induration of 10mm diameter or more at the site of inoculation indicates a positive test.
  • A positive test confirms past infection with tubercle bacilli but does not indicate the presence of the active stage. (Option C ruled out)
  • The test becomes positive 4-6 weeks after infection or BCG vaccination.

Explanation of other options:

Schick test; Confirmed TB diagnosis (Option A): Schick test is an intradermal test to demonstrate circulating diphtheria toxin.

Mantoux test; Latent TB diagnosis (Option B): The Mantoux test can indicate a latent TB infection, but it is not specific

questions.text: A 40-year-old female was admitted to the hospital with fever, loss of appetite and weight, cough and weakness of 3 months duration. She died a few days after admission. Autopsy findings of the gross lung and its biopsy findings have been shown. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gross lung shows upper lobe cavitations, and biopsy shows caseating granuloma suggestive of tuberculosis.

  • Tuberculosis typically occurs in the upper lobes and is often associated with cavity formation.
  • As sensitisation develops, a 1 to 1.5-cm area of grey-white inflammation with consolidation forms, known as the Ghon focus. In most cases, the centre of this focus undergoes caseous necrosis.
  • Tubercle bacilli, either free or within phagocytes, drain to the regional nodes, which also often caseate.
  • This combination of parenchymal lung lesion and nodal involvement is referred to as the Ghon complex.
  • Histologically, sites of active involvement are marked by a characteristic granulomatous inflammatory reaction that forms both caseating and noncaseating tubercles.
  • The granulomas are usually enclosed within a fibroblastic rim punctuated by lymphocytes. Multinucleated giant cells are present in the granulomas.

Explanation of other options:

Sarcoidosis (Option A): Sarcoidosis always shows non-caseating granulomas in histology, but it is a chronic granulomatous inflammatory condition with systemic involvement. Granulomas also contain asteroid and Schaumann bodies.

Carcinoma lung (Option B): Histopathology of the lung will show neoplastic changes, and they present with cough, shortness of breath and weight loss; fever is unlikely.

Bronchiectasis (Option D): In bronchiectasis, microscopically, inflammatory exudation within the walls of the bronchi and bronchioles, with desquamation of the lining epithelium and extensive ulceration, can be seen.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with severe respiratory distress, high-grade fever and streaks of blood in sputum. He died 7 days after hospitalisation. The histopathology image of the lung autopsy is shown below. Identify the associated pathology.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clinical presentation of high-grade fever and respiratory distress, and the gross specimen of the lung showing consolidation of a large portion of the entire lower lobe, indicating grey hepatisation, is seen in lobar pneumonia.

  • Consolidation of a large portion of a lobe or an entire lobe defines lobar pneumonia.
  • In lobar pneumonia, four stages of the inflammatory response have classically been described: congestion, red hepatisation, grey hepatisation, and resolution.

Explanation of other options:

Bronchopneumonia (Option B): Patchy consolidation of the lung is the dominant characteristic of bronchopneumonia. The consolidation may be confined to one lobe but is more often multilobar and frequently bilateral and basal because of the tendency of secretions to gravitate to the lower lobes.

Tuberculosis (Option C): In tuberculosis, cavitation is a prominent feature, and uniform consolidation is not seen; patients present with chronic symptoms.

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option D): Typically shows a mass lesion in the hilum or central bronchi rather than consolidation and clinically presents with gradually worsening respiratory symptoms and weight loss.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presented with a lesion at the apex of the lung. He has an occupational history of 20 years working in an asbestos factory. A lung biopsy examined under an electron microscope revealed the following findings. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Electron microscopy shows long microvilli and abundant tonofilaments, which are associated with mesothelioma. Prolonged asbestos exposure increases the risk of mesothelioma.

Mesothelioma:

  • Malignant tumour of the pleura.
  • These are peripheral tumours, often confused with adenocarcinoma.
  • Morphology: Biphasic tumours, having both epithelial (glands) and mesenchymal (stroma) components.
  • Often associated with pleural plaques, and histology shows asbestos bodies and ferruginous bodies.

Causes

  • Acquired:
    • The most popular cause is asbestos exposure.
    • Has a long latency period, about 20-40 years.
  • Genetic:
    • The most common genetic mutation is p16.
    • Also associated with BAP1 (BRCA1-associated protein 1) and NF2 (Neurofibromatosis type 2).

Diagnosis:

  • Electron microscopy: It has long and thin microvilli.
  • Also shows desmosomes (like SCC) and abundant tonofilaments.
  • IHC: Very typically positive for Calretinin. Also positive for WT1, D2-40 (Podoplanin), CK 5/6.

Explanation of other options:

Adenocarcinoma lung (Option A): Adenocarcinoma has a strong association with tobacco smoking and commonly arises in the peripheral lung. Electron microscopy shows short and stout microvilli.

Lung metastasis (Option C): These are secondary tumours arising from primary lung malignancy and can occur anywhere in the body. Electron microscopy will vary depending on the location of secondary tumours.

Benign pleural fibroma (Option D): It's a soft tissue tumour with a propensity to occur in the pleura and, less commonly, in the lung, as well as other sites. Microscopically, the tumour shows whorls of reticulin and collagen fibres among which are interspersed spindle cells resembling fibroblasts. Electron microscopy will not show microvilli.

Key Takeaways:

Epithelial cells, giant cells, and macrophages
Epithelioid cells, Langerhans giant cells, macrophages

questions.text: The chest radiograph from a patient with a history of low-grade fever, chronic cough and weight loss showed cavitatory lesions. Which of the following cell types are primarily responsible for these lesions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical presentation with cavitary lesions in the chest x-ray suggests tuberculosis. Cavitatory lesions in TB result from an immune-mediated response involving epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells, and macrophages, which form granulomas that undergo caseous necrosis and cavitation.

TB Pathogenesis:

  • M.tuberculosis enters macrophages by phagocytosis. Bacteria proliferate in the pulmonary alveolar macrophages and air spaces, resulting in bacteremia and seeding of multiple sites.
  • These result in innate and adaptive immune responses to M. tuberculosis, causing Th1-mediated macrophage activation and killing of bacteria.
  • In addition to stimulating macrophages to kill mycobacteria, the Th1 response orchestrates the formation of granulomas and caseous necrosis.
  • Macrophages activated by IFN-γ differentiate into the epithelioid histiocytes that aggregate to form granulomas; some epithelioid cells may fuse to form multinucleated giant cells (Langhans giant cells).

Histology features:

  • Histologically, sites of active involvement are marked by a characteristic granulomatous inflammatory reaction that forms both caseating and noncaseating tubercles.
  • Individual tubercles are microscopic; it is only when multiple granulomas coalesce that they become macroscopically visible.
  • The granulomas are usually enclosed within a fibroblastic rim punctuated by lymphocytes. Multinucleated giant cells are present in the granulomas.

Fig: Tuberculous granuloma showing an area of central necrosis surrounded by multiple Langhans-type giant cells, epithelioid cells, and lymphocytes.
